Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the parent needs to respond
Situation2: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Story: I stared at my phone, heart pounding. The school had just called—my son was caught bullying a classmate. As a parent, I knew I had to go to the school, talk to the teacher, and show my child that I take this seriously. But just as I was about to leave, my phone buzzed again. It was a message from my closest friend, Sarah. She sounded upset, hurt by a text I’d sent earlier. She wrote, “I can’t believe you’d say that to me.” I knew I had to call her right away, explain what I meant, and clear up the misunderstanding before it grew into something bigger. I felt torn in two. My child needed me to be present, to guide him through this difficult moment. But my friend needed me, too, to reassure her and save our friendship. Both roles demanded my immediate attention, and I could feel the weight of their expectations pressing down on me, making it hard to breathe. I stood in the hallway, phone in hand, paralyzed by the impossible choice.
